Review for (Bridge too) Far From the Tree:

Part 1:

-SPOILERS-

>Such a comfy and sweet story, even if a little tragic. Really nails the feelings of family with Trish and Toby. Which is paralleled with Hugh and Louie.

>It's definitely an improvement over Breaking the Ice (Queen) in terms of writing. Sentence structure has improved and so has your description and paragraphing.

>I liked Trish's characterisation and interaction. Showing how she can go from slutty to genuinely caring and heartfelt. A well rounded character indeed.

>I liked the continued world building. Even something subtle like the door handles.

>I enjoyed how it links to the wider mythos and breaking the Ice Queen. The continued world building and particular use of scent for Trish. It puts her apart from the last story with a human POV. Anonymous Thu 04 Nov 2021 08:43:33 No.42904720 Report
Quoted By: >>42905380
>>42904004
>Bothan
Nah, you're good here.
https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Bothan/Legends

You have some pretty rich potential for a Bothan waifur traveling with her bounty hunter. Pic related is even a fanfic of exactly that. They are as unique as individuals as any other species, including humans, despite the very general summary of their society. They serve in militarys, in the Jedi and with the Sith, fight as rebel pilots, operate as independents, mercenaries, etc. all in addition to those who serve the Bothan government in various capacities. They are known for their spycraft ... so, bounty hunter could just be a cover. Or, waifur of a bounty hunter could just be deep cover from which she can surface once critical mission goals are achieved. Or she could be a spy gone ronin and is using her skillz to survive in the bounty hunter ecology.

Let your imagination run wild. She can be good or evil or neutral, serving her government, any other government or cause, or just herself and her pet bounty hunter. She could be the actual bounty hunter of the pair, and the so-called "bounty hunter" who is her mate is just her useful muscle while she actually runs their operation from the shadows.

Take a deeper dive into Bothan lore and fandom. You don't need to look further, you've already found a solid character potential. But, seriously, if you're going to write a relationship, do more research here and decide on canon racial, personality, & social aspects that would most likely fit her no matter how she expresses them individually.

Anonymous Thu 04 Nov 2021 11:50:10 No.42906715 Report
Quoted By:
>>42906541
Whether or not it's absurdly huge depends on a number of factors, chiefly the industrial capacity of the society operating it and its purpose. I'd expect space cargo haulers to be fairly large, giving that they're servicing entire planets. Personally I've always regarded the stereotypical "free trader" of science fiction to be kind of bullshit. I can't imagine there being much value in a vessel with a cargo capacity South of the typical riverine cargo ship making runs between planets. I could also imagine a large vessel being controlled by one person, given that this is science fiction. Automation might be incredibly high, and it's a fairly regular theme anyhow. This is also one of those places where theme and flavor are serviced above (certain conceptions of) realism. It needs to be a single dude on a space ship, so it's a single dude on a space ship.

A fifth of the vessel being devoted to the quarters of a single individual sounds kind of crazy, though. Does this guy have a football field staffed by robots or something? Also, the sort of company/government that'd send a single dude into space for efficiency's sake would not then also devote a fifth of the ship's capacity to keeping him comfortable.

Anonymous Thu 04 Nov 2021 14:11:32 No.42908489 Report
Quoted By:
>>42908165
My advice is to work it into descriptions and actions. It's different for everyone, but I prefer the type of writing that considers the viewpoint of the people in it. Exposition can easily feel like an aside to the reader, which takes me out of it. To use a simple example:

>Raising her 4 fingered paw at Yvarra, Fenri greeted her.

That takes me out of it because this species wouldn't consider to count their digits, as it's natural to them. That's something that would come up later, or in the course of a natural description, such as them counting on their fingers. Who knows, maybe their numerical system is based on 8?

Also, those Trek technical manuals are bullshit. The Enterprise moves at the speed of plot. I love Trek, but it's apparent from some episodes that the writers knew nothing about the size and scale of the stuff they were describing. Except that the ships themselves are, ironically, of reasonable size.

Try to keep in mind you're writing a story about characters and not a lore manual. Giving a visual impression of the ship would go a lot farther than giving measurements. A lot of scifi and fantasy detail can be generalized when telling a story.

Anonymous Thu 04 Nov 2021 18:44:45 No.42913416 Report
Quoted By:
>>42913083
In a world without an ocean, salt must be mined from salt deposits in the ground, which are extant. However in a small world with no oceans there's also much less demand for preserved foodstuffs and so accordingly less investment into salt mining, thus also lowering supply. I assumed that the lowering of supply would be greater than the lowering of demand, thus increasing prices.

It's actually a misnomer that "salary" is derived from the Latin word for "salt", but that's something a bit beyond this conversation. Salt's value in the real world for most of history was as a preservative. In a smaller world with no seasons or seas there is no need for that, so it would only be used as medicine or "spice".

>>42913274
I try to but then I get sidetracked with the consequences of my own actions or just get weird ideas with my world. Did you know it's a plausible outcome to have a werewolf hunter who'd look like a Smurf?

Allow me to explain: werewolves are traditionally harmed by silver and so it could be assumed that silver in any form is toxic to them. Thus someone having silver in their bloodstream would have a method - an expensive method but a method - to cause serious harm if bitten.

Colloidal silver is a substance with no actual medicinal value, but it was believed to have it. It's silver particles suspended in water. Prolonged drinking of it can turn someone's skin blue.

Thus, a werewolf hunter who drank colloidal silver to ward off werewolf teeth and claws over the decades could eventually dye himself a deep blue color.
Anonymous

Anonymous Thu 04 Nov 2021 18:47:04 No.42913456 Report
Quoted By: >>42913536 >>42913634
>>42913330
Salt exposition anon here. Absurdism works but everything needs an internal logic, no matter how absurd. The best absurdism and the best parody uses /perfectly sound logic/ to advance ludicrous premise to astounding conclusion IMO.

Even the most ridiculous setting must take itself "seriously" to the extent where it's either consistent or has a means to explain inconsistencies. Otherwise there's never going to be a story.
